newsitem.title: UK: New UK agency seen taking over food safety role.
newsitem.headline: New UK agency seen taking over food safety role.

text.p: A new agency would take on responsibility for the safety of British food from the farm ministry under proposals in a report sought by new Labour Party Prime Minister Tony Blair that was published on Thursday.
Blair, when his party was in opposition to a Conservative government before his May 1 landslide election victory, had asked university professor Philip James for the report.

The James report was issued against a background of alarm about Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) or "Mad Cow" disease and concern that the farm ministry may be too sensitive to lobbyists for farmers and sections of the food industry.
"Many national surveys reveal that the public has lost confidence in the safety of British food," James reported.

"Secrecy characterises decision-making and inappropriate political and industrial interests are perceived to determine decisions on food safety to the detriment of public health and consumer interests," he said.
The agency that James envisaged would report to parliament through the health ministry. He suggested it be called "The Food and Health Commission."
A basic goal would be to reestablish public confidence in the way problems with food are handled within three years.
Besides BSE, Britons have been alarmed by an outbreak in Scotland of E.coli food poisoning that killed 20 people.
"The escalating rates of food-borne infection bear witness to the unsatisfactory state of current food safety measures," James said.

He recommends that the new agency be established as a non-departmental public body, along the lines of the existing Health and Safety Commission/Executive. It should have consumer and other public interest involvement within its structure.
The agency's funding should be the responsibility of health ministers and it should report to parliament through them.
"Other ministers, such as the minister of agriculture, however, will retain a substantial and legitimate interest in this policy area." James added.
He proposed a commission with about 10 members to oversee the agency.
James accepted that it is unlikely that the necessary legislation could be introduced before 1998-99. But he suggested that a cabinet committee could take the proposals forward.
"As an interim measure elements of the agency, including the commission, could be formed rapidly, albeit in an advisory capacity," James said.
The food and drink manufacturers organisation, Food and Drink Federation, welcomed the recognition by the government of the importance of food safety.

"The restoration of consumer confidence in the safety of British food and in the implementation of food safety regulations should be the overriding objective of food safety arrangements," the FDF said in a statement responding to the report.
